<p><strong>A confluence of advances in biological science</strong> and accelerating development of computing, automation, and artificial intelligence is fueling a new wave of innovation. This <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/europes-bio-revolution-biological-innovations-for-complex-problems">Bio Revolution could have significant impact on economies and our lives</a>, from health and agriculture to consumer goods, and energy and materials. </p>
<p>Some innovations come with profound risks rooted in the self-sustaining, self-replicating, and interconnected nature of biology that argue for a serious and sustained debate about how this revolution should proceed. Accidents can have major consequences—and, especially if used unethically or maliciously, manipulating biology could become a Pandora’s box that, once opened, unleashes lasting damage to the health of humans, ecosystems, or both. The risks are particularly acute because many of the materials and tools are relatively cheap and accessible. Moreover, tackling these risks is complicated by a multiplicity of jurisdictional and cultural value systems, which makes collaboration and coordination across countries difficult.  </p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>COVID-19 and bio innovations</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The rapid spread around the world in spring 2020 of a new coronavirus—SARS-CoV-2—imposed heavy health and economic costs. While the impact of COVID 19 was still unfolding at the time of writing in April 2020, bio innovations had been deployed to aid the response. More needs to be done to cope effectively with pandemics of this nature, but here we share a snapshot of some of the contributions made by advances in biological science that we observed in the early days of this pandemic. </p>
<p><strong><em>Identification.</em></strong> The full genome of SARS-CoV-2 was sequenced and  published weeks after the novel coronavirus was identified. By comparison, it took several months to sequence and publish the SARS-CoV-1 virus that caused the SARS outbreak.</p>
<p><strong><em>Diagnosis.</em></strong> Advances in nucleic acid-based diagnostics have enabled more effective diagnosis. In the past decade, for instance, the continued miniaturization of reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) machines made the technology more accessible for use in the field.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="994531b8-5915-4589-81a2-272cfa1ebce5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="994531b8-5915-4589-81a2-272cfa1ebce5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> RT-PCR is a laboratory technique used to make large-scale copies of specific segments of DNA molecules rapidly and precisely outside the body from a mixture of DNA molecules.</span></span></span></a></span> <span>The speed of the diagnostics also significantly improved. </span>However, the many challenges with diagnosis during the COVID 19 crisis also highlighted the fact that ample room remains for further improvement of diagnostics. </p>
<p><em><strong>Vaccines.</strong></em> The speed and scale at which researchers launched efforts to develop a COVID 19 vaccine was remarkable. This agility was driven in large part by the public health urgency, but also reflected innovations such as faster and more versatile, nucleic acid-based vaccine production and AI-powered R&D. As of April 2020—around three months after SARSCoV-2 was sequenced—more than 60 vaccines were in the preclinical stage and seven were in Phase 1 trials, although whether these efforts prove successful remained unclear. In contrast, it took more than a year after the Zika epidemic began in 2015 to start Phase 1 trials.</p>
<p><em><strong>Treatment.</strong></em> New capabilities assisted in developing new treatments for those infected. Genetically engineered animals were used to develop potential therapies, including using mice to produce monoclonal antibodies and cows to produce polyclonal antibodies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e7223b7d-0e3c-4089-a952-dbcffe081288"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e7223b7d-0e3c-4089-a952-dbcffe081288" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> Monoclonal antibodies are man-made antibodies of predetermined specificity against targets made by identical immune cells derived from a unique parent cell. </span></span></span></a></span> Therapies using siRNA, RNAi, T-cells, and stem cells were also explored. Patient gene expression (mRNA) profiles were gathered into a biobank with the aim of using the repository to identify new therapies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d5d0237d-a27f-4dc6-9b2f-f388a9e4826a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d5d0237d-a27f-4dc6-9b2f-f388a9e4826a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> Small interfering RNA or siRNA is central to RNA interference. siRNA is a family of double-stranded non-coding RNA molecules, with typical lengths of 20 to 25 base pairs that regulate the expression of specific genes with complementary nucleotide sequences by degrading their mRNA transcripts, preventing translation. RNA interference (RNAi) is an evolutionarily conserved gene silencing technique in which specific genes can be regulated and suppressed at the RNA level. T-cells are lymphocyte immune cells that protect the body from pathogens and cancer cells.</span></span></span></a></span> The efficacy of such treatments remained to be proven as of April 2020. </p>
<p><strong><em>Epidemiology.</em></strong> Genomics was used to try to uncover population-level insights. In the case of SARS-CoV-2, its genome was regularly sequenced in different geographies and hotspots to look for mutations that could indicate its place of origin and transmission dynamics. More clearly needs to be done to improve our collective response to dangerous pandemics such as COVID 19. Bio innovations are ongoing, and the way we respond to future pandemics may look very different. For instance, in the future it may be possible to leverage emerging technologies such as AI-enabled epidemiology to predict outbreaks or use algorithms to predict the structure of proteins to enable faster drug discovery. <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a64d19ec-62fd-43e7-beac-53b7386af1c4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a64d19ec-62fd-43e7-beac-53b7386af1c4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">One company is using a computer program to predict the 3D shape of proteins based on that protein’s amino acids. Predicting the structure makes it easier to design drug molecules that are more likely to bind to the protein. See Faris Gulamali, AlphaFold algorithm predicts COVID 19 protein structures, InfoQ, March 31, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>However, new biological applications are already improving our response to global challenges including climate change and pandemics. Global responses to the novel coronavirus—SARS-CoV-2—illustrated substantial advances in biological science in just the past few years. The speed with which scientists sequenced the virus’s genome—weeks rather than months—bore witness to the new world of biology described in this research. However, sequencing is just the start: biological innovations are enabling the rapid introduction of clinical trials of vaccines, the search for effective therapies, and a deep investigation of both the origins and the transmission patterns of the virus. </p>
<!-- -->
<p>As much as 60 percent of the physical inputs to the global economy could, in principle, be produced biologically—about one-third of these inputs are biological materials (wood or animals bred for food) and the remaining two-thirds are nonbiological (plastics or fuels) but could potentially be produced or substituted using biology. Therefore, it is possible that bio innovations could impact up to 60 percent of physical inputs, although attaining that full potential is a long way off. Even modest progress toward it could transform economies, societies, and our lives, including what we eat and wear, the medicines we take, the fuels we use, and how we construct our physical world. In human health, at least 45 percent of the current global disease burden could be addressed using science that is conceivable today.</p>
<p>A pipeline of about 400 use cases, almost all scientifically feasible today, is already visible.  These applications alone could have direct economic impact of up to $4 trillion a year over the next ten to 20 years. More than half of this direct impact could be outside human health in domains such as agriculture and food, consumer products and services, and materials and energy production.  Taking into account potential knock-on effects, new applications yet to emerge, and additional scientific breakthroughs, the full potential could be far larger.   </p>

<p>The current innovation wave in biology has been propelled by a confluence of breakthroughs in the science itself, together with advances in computing, data analytics, machine learning, artificial intelligence (AI), and biological engineering that are enabling and accelerating the change. This revolution has been decades in the making. The $3 billion, 13-year effort to map the human genome that began in 1990 is a foundational building block, but the power of this map only began to materialize when it became cheaper and faster to sequence DNA. The cost of DNA sequencing has been decreasing at a rate faster than Moore’s Law. Advances in lower-cost and high-throughput screening have helped lower the costs of entry, accelerate the pace of experimentation, and generate new forms of data—to help us better understand biology. </p>
<p>Innovations are grouped into four arenas: (1) biomolecules—the mapping, measuring, and engineering of molecules; (2) biosystems—the engineering of cells, tissues, and organs; (3) biomachines—the interface between biology and machines; and (4) biocomputing—the use of cells or molecules such as DNA for computation (Exhibit 1). </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20bio%20revolution%20innovations%20transforming%20economies%20societies%20and%20our%20lives/svgz_mgi-biorevolution-web_exh1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A confluence of breakthroughs in biological science, with the development of computing, automation, and AI, are fueling a new wave of innovation." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20bio%20revolution%20innovations%20transforming%20economies%20societies%20and%20our%20lives/svgz_mgi-biorevolution-web_exh1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Major breakthroughs in each of the four arenas are reinforcing one another. In biomolecules and biosystems, advances in omics and molecular technologies are enhancing our understanding of biological processes, as well as enabling us to engineer biology. The ability also exists to engineer or modify a living cell to cure or prevent disease; for example, the groundbreaking CRISPR tool allows scientists to edit genes more quickly and precisely than previous techniques. Essentially the same process is being applied to manufacturing everything from textiles to meat. Advances in biomachines and biocomputing both involve deep interaction between biology and machines; it is becoming increasingly possible to measure neural signals and power precise neuroprosthetics. It is now also possible to store the world’s wealth of data using DNA. The storage density of DNA is about one million times that of hard-disk storage. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-EE0097052A1C4285B3D52BDF5BBF87E6-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Health care worker adjusting medical equipment" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-2" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 2</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>New biological capabilities could bring about meaningful change across economies and societies</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>New biological capabilities have the potential to bring sweeping change to economies and societies: </p>
<p><strong><em>Biological means could be used to produce a large share of the global economy’s physical materials, potentially with improved performance and sustainability.</em></strong>  Fermentation, for centuries used to make bread and brew beer, is now being used to create fabrics such as artificial spider silk. Biology is increasingly being used to create novel materials that have unique qualities, introduce entirely new capabilities, are biodegradable, and/or produced in a way that emits significantly less carbon. Some companies are already using genetically engineered microbes to create biofuels for the aviation and marine industries. </p>
<p><strong><em>Increased control and precision in methodology is occurring across the value chain, from delivery to development and consumption with more personalization.</em></strong> Advances in molecular biology have made R&D and delivery processes more precise, predictable, and deliberate—enabling rational design rather than discovery by accident. Increasing knowledge of human genomes and the links between certain genes and diseases is enabling the spread of personalized medicine and precision agriculture. </p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Technically, one kilogram of raw DNA could store the entirety of the world’s data. </p></blockquote></div>
<p><strong><em>The capability to engineer and reprogram human and nonhuman organisms is increasing.</em></strong> Gene therapies could offer complete cures of some diseases. Crops can be genetically engineered to produce higher yields and be more heat- or drought-resistant, for instance—traits that are becoming even more important given climate change. </p>
<p><strong><em>New methodologies using automation, machine learning, and proliferating biological data are enhancing discovery, throughput, and productivity in R&D.</em></strong> Biology and computing together are accelerating R&D, thereby addressing a productivity challenge. <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/digital-in-r-and-d-the-100-billion-opportunity">McKinsey analysis in 2017</a> found that the ratio of revenue to R&D spending in the biopharmaceutical industry hit a productivity nadir between 2008 and 2011. Biotech companies and research institutes are increasingly using robotic automation and sensors in labs that could increase throughput up to ten times. Advanced analytics using machine learning can provide better insights during the R&D process. </p>
<p><strong><em>Potential is growing for interfaces between biological systems and computers.</em></strong> A new generation of biomachine interfaces relies on close interaction between humans and computers. Such interfaces include neuroprosthetics that restore lost sensory functions (bionic vision) or enable signals from the brain to control physical movement. Biocomputers that use biology to mimic silicon are being researched, including the use of DNA to store data. DNA is about one million times denser than hard-disk storage; technically, one kilogram of raw DNA could store the entirety of the world’s data. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-FB5A704BDAD24F95970B97B795777B22-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Aisle" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-3" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 3</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Today’s pipeline of applications is a fraction of the far-reaching impacts expected ahead</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>For this research, a library of about 400 use cases was compiled that already constitute a  visible pipeline for the years ahead. The library comprises applications that are scientifically feasible today and likely to be commercially viable by 2050. Over the next ten to 20 years these applications alone could have direct economic impact of between $2 trillion and $4 trillion globally per year.  </p>
<p>Human health and performance has the clearest pipeline from research to commercialization. The science is advanced, and the market is generally accepting of innovations. However, more than half of the direct impact of the applications in the library over the next ten to 20 years is likely to be outside health, primarily in agriculture and consumer products (Exhibit 2). </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20bio%20revolution%20innovations%20transforming%20economies%20societies%20and%20our%20lives/svgz_mgi-biorevolution-web_exh2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="More than half of the impact is outside of healthcare in agriculture, consumer, and other areas." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/life%20sciences/our%20insights/the%20bio%20revolution%20innovations%20transforming%20economies%20societies%20and%20our%20lives/svgz_mgi-biorevolution-web_exh2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Over this period, applications will tend to be in four key domains: </p>
<p><em><strong>Human health and performance.</strong></em> Applications include cell, gene, and RNA therapies to treat or even prevent disease, a range of anti-aging treatments to extend lifespans, innovations in reproductive medicine, and improvements to drug development and delivery and new predictive modelling of human health and disease. Many more options are being explored and becoming available to treat monogenic (caused by a single gene) diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, polygenic diseases such as cardiovascular disease, and infectious diseases such as malaria. The direct annual global potential impact is estimated at $0.5 trillion to $1.3 trillion over the next ten to 20 years, or 35 percent of the total (including impact from biomachine interfaces).   </p>
<p><em><strong>Agriculture, aquaculture, and food.</strong></em> Applications in this domain include innovative new ways to conduct breeding of animals and plants using molecular or genetic markers that are many times quicker than established selective-breeding methods; new, more precise tools for the genetic engineering of plants; fast-developing work using the microbiome of plants, soil, animals, and water to improve the quality and productivity of agricultural production; and the development of alternative proteins including lab-grown meat. Direct annual impact could be between about $0.8 trillion and $1.2 trillion over the next ten to 20 years, or 36 percent of the total. </p>
<p><em><strong>Consumer products and services.</strong></em> Opportunities are opening up to use increasing volumes of biological data to offer consumers personalized products and services based on their biological makeup. Applications in this domain include direct-to-consumer genetic testing, beauty and personal care increasingly based on increased knowledge of the microbiome as microbiome testing spreads, and innovative approaches to wellness (or fitness) not only in humans but in pets. There could be annual direct economic impact over the next ten to 20 years of $200 billion and $800 billion, or 19 percent of the total (including impact from biomachine interfaces).  </p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The direct annual global impact of the Bio Revolution could be $2 trillion to $4 trillion in 2030-40.</p></blockquote></div>
<p><strong>Materials, chemicals, and energy.</strong> New biological ways of making and processing materials, chemicals, and energy could transform many industries and our daily lives, although the economics are challenging. Applications in this domain include innovations related to production of materials such as improved fermentation processes, new bioroutes utilizing the ability to edit the DNA of microbes to develop novel materials with entirely new properties (self-repairing fabrics is one example), and building on advances in biofuels to innovate new forms of energy storage. Over the next ten to 20 years, the direct annual global impact could be $200 billion to $300 billion a year, or 8 percent of the total. </p>
<p>Biology has many other potential applications, although some of these are likely to be further in the future. It could be deployed to help the environment through biosequestration—using biological processes to capture carbon emissions from the atmosphere—and bioremediation. Impact is also emerging in biomachine interfaces and biocomputing where the science and development is at an early stage but applications are promising. Applications that have already been developed include neuroprosthetics to restore hearing and vision. </p>
<p>The direct potential impact of the around 400 use cases may only be a small portion of the potential scale of impact. Many other innovations are being developed in private labs or in the defense industry where developments remain confidential for commercial or national security reasons. </p>
<p>Eventually impact will radiate out to almost every sector of the economy with effects on societies and the environment as biological innovation transforms profit pools, value chains, and business models. In the years ahead, if you are not using biology to make products, you will very likely be consuming them. The impact could go much further, with biology potentially being used to address some of the great challenges of our time including mitigating <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-risk-and-response-physical-hazards-and-socioeconomic-impacts">climate change</a>. By 2040 to 2050, the direct applications we sized could reduce annual average man-made greenhouse-gas emissions by 7 to 9 percent from 2018 emissions levels. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-081706BF5A844FBF870CC716C79A20F6-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Worker in a lab studying a specimen" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-4" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 4</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Biological innovation has profound and unique risks</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Profound risks accompany this surge of innovation in biology. Get it right and the benefits could be very significant; get it wrong and there could be disastrous consequences at the population level. These risks introduce a unique set of considerations which, if not managed properly, could potentially outweigh the promised benefits of a particular application: </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Biology is self-replicating, self-sustaining, and does not respect jurisdictional boundaries.</em> For example, new genetically engineered gene drives applied to the vectors that spread disease (mosquitoes in the case of malaria) could have enormous health benefits, but such gene drives can be difficult to control and can potentially permanently change ecosystems.
    </li>
    <li><em>The interconnected nature of biology can increase the potential for unintended consequences.</em> Changes to one part of the system can have cascading effects and unintended consequences across entire ecosystems or species. Gene editing could also have unintended or “off-target” effects.
    </li>
    <li><em>Low barriers to entry open the door to potential misuse with potentially fatal consequences.</em> Some biological technologies are relatively cheap and accessible. Commercial kits to perform CRISPR gene editing are being sold relatively cheaply on the internet.
    </li>
    <li><em>Differing value systems make it hard to forge consensus, including on life and death issues.</em> Technical and scientific issues, such as embryo editing, quickly become moral questions, and often, decisions across these issues are expressions of one’s value system.   The challenge of cooperation and coordination of value-systems across cultures and jurisdictions is no easy task, particularly when advances in these scientific domains could be seen as a unique competitive advantage for businesses or economies.
    </li>
    <li><em>Privacy and consent issues are fundamental.</em> Concerns about personal privacy and consent are rife, given that the cornerstone of biological advances is data mined from our bodies and brains.
    </li>
    <li><em>Unequal access could perpetuate socioeconomic disparity, with potentially regressive effects.</em> Biological advances and their commercial applications may not be accessible to all in equal measure, thereby exacerbating socioeconomic disparity. At a country level, developments are advancing quickest and most broadly in relatively rich countries. </li>
</ul>
<p>These risks demand a considered response and potentially new approaches. In past waves of technological change, regulation has emerged in response to innovations; in biology, there is a strong argument for a proactive approach. Regulation will be important, but so too will oversight and monitoring of science even as it develops. The choices scientists make will help determine what kinds of technologies develop. International collaboration and coordination will be valuable as biology doesn’t respect borders—as we experienced in early 2020 with the rapid spread of COVID-19.  </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-B6A5F8F6E7874817974CFC8EF0690886-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Neurological display" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-5" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 5</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>In the journey to adoption, science is just the starting point</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Risks need to be addressed, but beyond that there are many stages to negotiate as innovations move from the lab to adoption. The journey to adoption has three broad stages: scientific research; commercialization; and then diffusion. For biological applications to diffuse and deliver impact, six broad factors play a role; they determine whether adoption occurs and how long it takes:  </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Investment in scientific research.</em> Funding, tools, talent, and access to data are necessary and powerful elements of the investment needed to enable scientists to be successful. It tends to take years of research and sizable investment in these capabilities to get an idea to the point at which a product or service is scientifically feasible. </li>
    <li><em>Four factors play a role in commercialization and diffusion.</em> First, a new biology-based product or service needs to compete with existing products and services not only on cost but also by offering higher quality or new properties or, indeed, by meeting a need not fulfilled by existing offerings. The second factor is whether business models are suitable for what may be a fast-changing landscape. Third, a new biology-based product and service needs to hit the right potential customers with go-to-market elements including pricing, sales, and marketing. The fourth factor is the ability to scale up operations. </li>
    <li><em>Risk and mechanisms governing use.</em> Given the profound and unique risks accompanying biological innovation, mechanisms governing use, including broad acceptance from society and regulation, are key at all stages. About 70 percent of the total potential impact could hinge on consumer, societal, and regulatory acceptance, based on an analysis of areas where regulations exist today in major economies.</li>
</ul>
<p>The pace and extent of adoption will vary enormously depending on the application and the domain. Some applications including using new bioroutes to manufacture drugs are already showing robust signs of early commercial adoption. Others such as CAR T-cell therapy for cancer have recently become commercially viable, adoption is early, and could increase rapidly in the near term over the coming decade. Yet others such as using genetically engineered plants to sequester CO<sub>2</sub> show promise in scientific research but commercial viability and adoption by farmers or other buyers is likely further out (Exhibit 3).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="dark" data-module-background="deep-blue" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="top-right" class="mck-o-edge-to-edge SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header___N7qG mck-c-module-wrapper"><style></style><div data-component="mdc-c-background-image" class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c background-image-section-header-E7AE6D2D056B4D4D9CD2E9AB8E942ED5-bg SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__parallax-container__sgMMy" role="img" aria-label="Earth as seen in space" style="transform: translate(0px, 0px);"></div><div class="mdc-c-bg-image___GJdv1_990311c mdc-c-bg-image--opaque-bg___CauU1_990311c" style="opacity:0.3"></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing"><div id="section-header-6" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper__CZEyB" tabindex="-1"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-12 SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-positioned__fIWpF"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-sm SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__wrapper-text__hSx1f" style="display: none; opacity: 0;"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Section 6</span></div><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__heading__2ePOu"><span>Striking a balance that enables potential to be captured while managing risks</span></h2></div><div class="SectionHeader_mck-c-section-header__section-holder__BaLti"></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Given the breadth of change that likely lies ahead, innovators, businesses, governments, and individuals need to become literate in biological science in order to understand the fundamental shifts under way, seize the large potential benefits, but in a way that ensures that innovation is safe for citizens and society. </p>
<p><strong><em>Innovators.</em></strong> Scientists govern their own research processes. Peer review is a powerful internal governing mechanism to ensure that research is accurate and well grounded. But scientists cannot operate in a vacuum; to an extent, they need to take into account the views of society in the research they propagate. The scientific community must play a consistent and effective oversight role.</p>
<p><strong><em>Businesses should consider how to take advantage of biological innovation, potentially adapt strategies.</em></strong> The Bio Revolution could transform entire value chains, and companies in virtually every sector may need to adapt strategies. Given the uncertainty and evidently varied timing of adoption for different applications, companies should consider a portfolio-based approach toward investment. By its nature, biological innovation is cross-discipline and, as such, it is unlikely that any business that exists today can go it alone. Large companies should consider the degree to which they  develop the full range of necessary capabilities in-house or “buy in” what they need through mergers and acquisitions, and partnerships. As in the Digital Revolution, some companies should consider how to use platform-based business models that can seize cross-sector opportunities, reduce marginal costs, and drive combinatorial innovation by leveraging growing biological data. Among other aspects to consider are the range of opportunities for more personalized and precise offerings enabled by growing biological data, and innovative revenue models that could help accelerate diffusion. </p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The Bio Revolution could transform entire value chains, and companies in virtually every sector may need to adapt strategies.</p></blockquote></div>
<p><strong><em>Civil society, governments, and policy makers need to inform themselves about biological advances and respond to them effectively.</em></strong> Several governments including those of China, the United Kingdom, and the United States have set the tone for biological innovation with published strategic plans and goals intended to catalyze biological innovation and capture its benefits. However, innovation needs to be balanced by mechanisms to govern use and misuse, and whether existing professional and regulatory mechanisms are fit for purpose must be considered. </p>
<p><strong><em>Individuals and consumers may be pivotal to the adoption path of biological advances.</em></strong> To contribute effectively to what can be controversial debates (consider embryo editing as an example), individuals need to seek to understand the benefits versus the risks. They also need to appreciate that there are personal trade-offs. DTC testing, for instance, provides individuals with potentially valuable insights into the probability of contracting certain diseases, but mining that information may compromise their privacy. </p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The Bio Revolution Innovations transforming economies societies and our lives","displayName":"The Bio Revolution Innovations transforming economies societies and our lives","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"2783c1c6-cc17-4b30-a8f1-a805ba5151c1","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":3,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The Bio Revolution: Innovations transforming economies, societies, and our lives"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Advances in biological science could transform economies and societies, helping to tackle global challenges from climate change to pandemics."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-05-13T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA confluence of advances in biological science\u003c/strong\u003e and accelerating development of computing, automation, and artificial intelligence is fueling a new wave of innovation. This \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/europes-bio-revolution-biological-innovations-for-complex-problems\"\u003eBio Revolution could have significant impact on economies and our lives\u003c/a\u003e, from health and agriculture to consumer goods, and energy and materials. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome innovations come with profound risks rooted in the self-sustaining, self-replicating, and interconnected nature of biology that argue for a serious and sustained debate about how this revolution should proceed. Accidents can have major consequences\u0026mdash;and, especially if used unethically or maliciously, manipulating biology could become a Pandora\u0026rsquo;s box that, once opened, unleashes lasting damage to the health of humans, ecosystems, or both. The risks are particularly acute because many of the materials and tools are relatively cheap and accessible. Moreover, tackling these risks is complicated by a multiplicity of jurisdictional and cultural value systems, which makes collaboration and coordination across countries difficult.  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar covid]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, new biological applications are already improving our response to global challenges including climate change and pandemics. Global responses to the novel coronavirus\u0026mdash;SARS-CoV-2\u0026mdash;illustrated substantial advances in biological science in just the past few years. The speed with which scientists sequenced the virus\u0026rsquo;s genome\u0026mdash;weeks rather than months\u0026mdash;bore witness to the new world of biology described in this research. However, sequencing is just the start: biological innovations are enabling the rapid introduction of clinical trials of vaccines, the search for effective therapies, and a deep investigation of both the origins and the transmission patterns of the virus. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs much as 60 percent of the physical inputs to the global economy could, in principle, be produced biologically\u0026mdash;about one-third of these inputs are biological materials (wood or animals bred for food) and the remaining two-thirds are nonbiological (plastics or fuels) but could potentially be produced or substituted using biology. Therefore, it is possible that bio innovations could impact up to 60 percent of physical inputs, although attaining that full potential is a long way off. Even modest progress toward it could transform economies, societies, and our lives, including what we eat and wear, the medicines we take, the fuels we use, and how we construct our physical world. In human health, at least 45 percent of the current global disease burden could be addressed using science that is conceivable today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA pipeline of about 400 use cases, almost all scientifically feasible today, is already visible.  These applications alone could have direct economic impact of up to $4 trillion a year over the next ten to 20 years. More than half of this direct impact could be outside human health in domains such as agriculture and food, consumer products and services, and materials and energy production.  Taking into account potential knock-on effects, new applications yet to emerge, and additional scientific breakthroughs, the full potential could be far larger.   \u003c/p\u003e\n[[TableOfContents]]\n[[SectionHeader 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe current innovation wave in biology has been propelled by a confluence of breakthroughs in the science itself, together with advances in computing, data analytics, machine learning, artificial intelligence (AI), and biological engineering that are enabling and accelerating the change. This revolution has been decades in the making. The $3 billion, 13-year effort to map the human genome that began in 1990 is a foundational building block, but the power of this map only began to materialize when it became cheaper and faster to sequence DNA. The cost of DNA sequencing has been decreasing at a rate faster than Moore\u0026rsquo;s Law. Advances in lower-cost and high-throughput screening have helped lower the costs of entry, accelerate the pace of experimentation, and generate new forms of data\u0026mdash;to help us better understand biology. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInnovations are grouped into four arenas: (1) biomolecules\u0026mdash;the mapping, measuring, and engineering of molecules; (2) biosystems\u0026mdash;the engineering of cells, tissues, and organs; (3) biomachines\u0026mdash;the interface between biology and machines; and (4) biocomputing\u0026mdash;the use of cells or molecules such as DNA for computation (Exhibit 1). \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eMajor breakthroughs in each of the four arenas are reinforcing one another. In biomolecules and biosystems, advances in omics and molecular technologies are enhancing our understanding of biological processes, as well as enabling us to engineer biology. The ability also exists to engineer or modify a living cell to cure or prevent disease; for example, the groundbreaking CRISPR tool allows scientists to edit genes more quickly and precisely than previous techniques. Essentially the same process is being applied to manufacturing everything from textiles to meat. Advances in biomachines and biocomputing both involve deep interaction between biology and machines; it is becoming increasingly possible to measure neural signals and power precise neuroprosthetics. It is now also possible to store the world\u0026rsquo;s wealth of data using DNA. The storage density of DNA is about one million times that of hard-disk storage. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eNew biological capabilities have the potential to bring sweeping change to economies and societies: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBiological means could be used to produce a large share of the global economy\u0026rsquo;s physical materials, potentially with improved performance and sustainability.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e  Fermentation, for centuries used to make bread and brew beer, is now being used to create fabrics such as artificial spider silk. Biology is increasingly being used to create novel materials that have unique qualities, introduce entirely new capabilities, are biodegradable, and/or produced in a way that emits significantly less carbon. Some companies are already using genetically engineered microbes to create biofuels for the aviation and marine industries. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eIncreased control and precision in methodology is occurring across the value chain, from delivery to development and consumption with more personalization.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Advances in molecular biology have made R\u0026amp;D and delivery processes more precise, predictable, and deliberate\u0026mdash;enabling rational design rather than discovery by accident. Increasing knowledge of human genomes and the links between certain genes and diseases is enabling the spread of personalized medicine and precision agriculture. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe capability to engineer and reprogram human and nonhuman organisms is increasing.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Gene therapies could offer complete cures of some diseases. Crops can be genetically engineered to produce higher yields and be more heat- or drought-resistant, for instance\u0026mdash;traits that are becoming even more important given climate change. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eNew methodologies using automation, machine learning, and proliferating biological data are enhancing discovery, throughput, and productivity in R\u0026amp;D.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Biology and computing together are accelerating R\u0026amp;D, thereby addressing a productivity challenge. \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/digital-in-r-and-d-the-100-billion-opportunity\"\u003eMcKinsey analysis in 2017\u003c/a\u003e found that the ratio of revenue to R\u0026amp;D spending in the biopharmaceutical industry hit a productivity nadir between 2008 and 2011. Biotech companies and research institutes are increasingly using robotic automation and sensors in labs that could increase throughput up to ten times. Advanced analytics using machine learning can provide better insights during the R\u0026amp;D process. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ePotential is growing for interfaces between biological systems and computers.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e A new generation of biomachine interfaces relies on close interaction between humans and computers. Such interfaces include neuroprosthetics that restore lost sensory functions (bionic vision) or enable signals from the brain to control physical movement. Biocomputers that use biology to mimic silicon are being researched, including the use of DNA to store data. DNA is about one million times denser than hard-disk storage; technically, one kilogram of raw DNA could store the entirety of the world\u0026rsquo;s data. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eFor this research, a library of about 400 use cases was compiled that already constitute a  visible pipeline for the years ahead. The library comprises applications that are scientifically feasible today and likely to be commercially viable by 2050. Over the next ten to 20 years these applications alone could have direct economic impact of between $2 trillion and $4 trillion globally per year.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHuman health and performance has the clearest pipeline from research to commercialization. The science is advanced, and the market is generally accepting of innovations. However, more than half of the direct impact of the applications in the library over the next ten to 20 years is likely to be outside health, primarily in agriculture and consumer products (Exhibit 2). \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eOver this period, applications will tend to be in four key domains: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHuman health and performance.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Applications include cell, gene, and RNA therapies to treat or even prevent disease, a range of anti-aging treatments to extend lifespans, innovations in reproductive medicine, and improvements to drug development and delivery and new predictive modelling of human health and disease. Many more options are being explored and becoming available to treat monogenic (caused by a single gene) diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, polygenic diseases such as cardiovascular disease, and infectious diseases such as malaria. The direct annual global potential impact is estimated at $0.5 trillion to $1.3 trillion over the next ten to 20 years, or 35 percent of the total (including impact from biomachine interfaces).   \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAgriculture, aquaculture, and food.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Applications in this domain include innovative new ways to conduct breeding of animals and plants using molecular or genetic markers that are many times quicker than established selective-breeding methods; new, more precise tools for the genetic engineering of plants; fast-developing work using the microbiome of plants, soil, animals, and water to improve the quality and productivity of agricultural production; and the development of alternative proteins including lab-grown meat. Direct annual impact could be between about $0.8 trillion and $1.2 trillion over the next ten to 20 years, or 36 percent of the total. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsumer products and services.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Opportunities are opening up to use increasing volumes of biological data to offer consumers personalized products and services based on their biological makeup. Applications in this domain include direct-to-consumer genetic testing, beauty and personal care increasingly based on increased knowledge of the microbiome as microbiome testing spreads, and innovative approaches to wellness (or fitness) not only in humans but in pets. There could be annual direct economic impact over the next ten to 20 years of $200 billion and $800 billion, or 19 percent of the total (including impact from biomachine interfaces).  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMaterials, chemicals, and energy.\u003c/strong\u003e New biological ways of making and processing materials, chemicals, and energy could transform many industries and our daily lives, although the economics are challenging. Applications in this domain include innovations related to production of materials such as improved fermentation processes, new bioroutes utilizing the ability to edit the DNA of microbes to develop novel materials with entirely new properties (self-repairing fabrics is one example), and building on advances in biofuels to innovate new forms of energy storage. Over the next ten to 20 years, the direct annual global impact could be $200 billion to $300 billion a year, or 8 percent of the total. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBiology has many other potential applications, although some of these are likely to be further in the future. It could be deployed to help the environment through biosequestration\u0026mdash;using biological processes to capture carbon emissions from the atmosphere\u0026mdash;and bioremediation. Impact is also emerging in biomachine interfaces and biocomputing where the science and development is at an early stage but applications are promising. Applications that have already been developed include neuroprosthetics to restore hearing and vision. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe direct potential impact of the around 400 use cases may only be a small portion of the potential scale of impact. Many other innovations are being developed in private labs or in the defense industry where developments remain confidential for commercial or national security reasons. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEventually impact will radiate out to almost every sector of the economy with effects on societies and the environment as biological innovation transforms profit pools, value chains, and business models. In the years ahead, if you are not using biology to make products, you will very likely be consuming them. The impact could go much further, with biology potentially being used to address some of the great challenges of our time including mitigating \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-risk-and-response-physical-hazards-and-socioeconomic-impacts\"\u003eclimate change\u003c/a\u003e. By 2040 to 2050, the direct applications we sized could reduce annual average man-made greenhouse-gas emissions by 7 to 9 percent from 2018 emissions levels. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eProfound risks accompany this surge of innovation in biology. Get it right and the benefits could be very significant; get it wrong and there could be disastrous consequences at the population level. These risks introduce a unique set of considerations which, if not managed properly, could potentially outweigh the promised benefits of a particular application: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBiology is self-replicating, self-sustaining, and does not respect jurisdictional boundaries.\u003c/em\u003e For example, new genetically engineered gene drives applied to the vectors that spread disease (mosquitoes in the case of malaria) could have enormous health benefits, but such gene drives can be difficult to control and can potentially permanently change ecosystems.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe interconnected nature of biology can increase the potential for unintended consequences.\u003c/em\u003e Changes to one part of the system can have cascading effects and unintended consequences across entire ecosystems or species. Gene editing could also have unintended or \u0026ldquo;off-target\u0026rdquo; effects.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLow barriers to entry open the door to potential misuse with potentially fatal consequences.\u003c/em\u003e Some biological technologies are relatively cheap and accessible. Commercial kits to perform CRISPR gene editing are being sold relatively cheaply on the internet.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDiffering value systems make it hard to forge consensus, including on life and death issues.\u003c/em\u003e Technical and scientific issues, such as embryo editing, quickly become moral questions, and often, decisions across these issues are expressions of one\u0026rsquo;s value system.   The challenge of cooperation and coordination of value-systems across cultures and jurisdictions is no easy task, particularly when advances in these scientific domains could be seen as a unique competitive advantage for businesses or economies.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePrivacy and consent issues are fundamental.\u003c/em\u003e Concerns about personal privacy and consent are rife, given that the cornerstone of biological advances is data mined from our bodies and brains.\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnequal access could perpetuate socioeconomic disparity, with potentially regressive effects.\u003c/em\u003e Biological advances and their commercial applications may not be accessible to all in equal measure, thereby exacerbating socioeconomic disparity. At a country level, developments are advancing quickest and most broadly in relatively rich countries. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese risks demand a considered response and potentially new approaches. In past waves of technological change, regulation has emerged in response to innovations; in biology, there is a strong argument for a proactive approach. Regulation will be important, but so too will oversight and monitoring of science even as it develops. The choices scientists make will help determine what kinds of technologies develop. International collaboration and coordination will be valuable as biology doesn\u0026rsquo;t respect borders\u0026mdash;as we experienced in early 2020 with the rapid spread of COVID-19.  \u003c/p\u003e\n[[SectionHeader 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eRisks need to be addressed, but beyond that there are many stages to negotiate as innovations move from the lab to adoption. The journey to adoption has three broad stages: scientific research; commercialization; and then diffusion. For biological applications to diffuse and deliver impact, six broad factors play a role; they determine whether adoption occurs and how long it takes:  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvestment in scientific research.\u003c/em\u003e Funding, tools, talent, and access to data are necessary and powerful elements of the investment needed to enable scientists to be successful. It tends to take years of research and sizable investment in these capabilities to get an idea to the point at which a product or service is scientifically feasible. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFour factors play a role in commercialization and diffusion.\u003c/em\u003e First, a new biology-based product or service needs to compete with existing products and services not only on cost but also by offering higher quality or new properties or, indeed, by meeting a need not fulfilled by existing offerings. The second factor is whether business models are suitable for what may be a fast-changing landscape. Third, a new biology-based product and service needs to hit the right potential customers with go-to-market elements including pricing, sales, and marketing. The fourth factor is the ability to scale up operations. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRisk and mechanisms governing use.\u003c/em\u003e Given the profound and unique risks accompanying biological innovation, mechanisms governing use, including broad acceptance from society and regulation, are key at all stages. About 70 percent of the total potential impact could hinge on consumer, societal, and regulatory acceptance, based on an analysis of areas where regulations exist today in major economies.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pace and extent of adoption will vary enormously depending on the application and the domain. Some applications including using new bioroutes to manufacture drugs are already showing robust signs of early commercial adoption. Others such as CAR T-cell therapy for cancer have recently become commercially viable, adoption is early, and could increase rapidly in the near term over the coming decade. Yet others such as using genetically engineered plants to sequester CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e show promise in scientific research but commercial viability and adoption by farmers or other buyers is likely further out (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n[[SectionHeader 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eGiven the breadth of change that likely lies ahead, innovators, businesses, governments, and individuals need to become literate in biological science in order to understand the fundamental shifts under way, seize the large potential benefits, but in a way that ensures that innovation is safe for citizens and society. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eInnovators.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Scientists govern their own research processes. Peer review is a powerful internal governing mechanism to ensure that research is accurate and well grounded. But scientists cannot operate in a vacuum; to an extent, they need to take into account the views of society in the research they propagate. The scientific community must play a consistent and effective oversight role.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusinesses should consider how to take advantage of biological innovation, potentially adapt strategies.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e The Bio Revolution could transform entire value chains, and companies in virtually every sector may need to adapt strategies. Given the uncertainty and evidently varied timing of adoption for different applications, companies should consider a portfolio-based approach toward investment. By its nature, biological innovation is cross-discipline and, as such, it is unlikely that any business that exists today can go it alone. Large companies should consider the degree to which they  develop the full range of necessary capabilities in-house or \u0026ldquo;buy in\u0026rdquo; what they need through mergers and acquisitions, and partnerships. As in the Digital Revolution, some companies should consider how to use platform-based business models that can seize cross-sector opportunities, reduce marginal costs, and drive combinatorial innovation by leveraging growing biological data. Among other aspects to consider are the range of opportunities for more personalized and precise offerings enabled by growing biological data, and innovative revenue models that could help accelerate diffusion. \u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 3]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eCivil society, governments, and policy makers need to inform themselves about biological advances and respond to them effectively.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Several governments including those of China, the United Kingdom, and the United States have set the tone for biological innovation with published strategic plans and goals intended to catalyze biological innovation and capture its benefits. However, innovation needs to be balanced by mechanisms to govern use and misuse, and whether existing professional and regulatory mechanisms are fit for purpose must be considered. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eIndividuals and consumers may be pivotal to the adoption path of biological advances.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e To contribute effectively to what can be controversial debates (consider embryo editing as an example), individuals need to seek to understand the benefits versus the risks. They also need to appreciate that there are personal trade-offs. DTC testing, for instance, provides individuals with potentially valuable insights into the probability of contracting certain diseases, but mining that information may compromise their privacy. While the impact of COVID 19 was still unfolding at the time of writing in April 2020, bio innovations had been deployed to aid the response. More needs to be done to cope effectively with pandemics of this nature, but here we share a snapshot of some of the contributions made by advances in biological science that we observed in the early days of this pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdentification.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e The full genome of SARS-CoV-2 was sequenced and  published weeks after the novel coronavirus was identified. By comparison, it took several months to sequence and publish the SARS-CoV-1 virus that caused the SARS outbreak.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eDiagnosis.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Advances in nucleic acid-based diagnostics have enabled more effective diagnosis. In the past decade, for instance, the continued miniaturization of reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) machines made the technology more accessible for use in the field.[[footnote 1]] \u003cspan\u003eThe speed of the diagnostics also significantly improved. \u003c/span\u003eHowever, the many challenges with diagnosis during the COVID 19 crisis also highlighted the fact that ample room remains for further improvement of diagnostics. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVaccines.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e The speed and scale at which researchers launched efforts to develop a COVID 19 vaccine was remarkable. This agility was driven in large part by the public health urgency, but also reflected innovations such as faster and more versatile, nucleic acid-based vaccine production and AI-powered R\u0026amp;D. As of April 2020\u0026mdash;around three months after SARSCoV-2 was sequenced\u0026mdash;more than 60 vaccines were in the preclinical stage and seven were in Phase 1 trials, although whether these efforts prove successful remained unclear. In contrast, it took more than a year after the Zika epidemic began in 2015 to start Phase 1 trials.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTreatment.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e New capabilities assisted in developing new treatments for those infected. Genetically engineered animals were used to develop potential therapies, including using mice to produce monoclonal antibodies and cows to produce polyclonal antibodies.[[footnote 2]] Therapies using siRNA, RNAi, T-cells, and stem cells were also explored. Patient gene expression (mRNA) profiles were gathered into a biobank with the aim of using the repository to identify new therapies.[[footnote 3]] The efficacy of such treatments remained to be proven as of April 2020. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEpidemiology.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Genomics was used to try to uncover population-level insights. In the case of SARS-CoV-2, its genome was regularly sequenced in different geographies and hotspots to look for mutations that could indicate its place of origin and transmission dynamics. More clearly needs to be done to improve our collective response to dangerous pandemics such as COVID 19. Bio innovations are ongoing, and the way we respond to future pandemics may look very different. For instance, in the future it may be possible to leverage emerging technologies such as AI-enabled epidemiology to predict outbreaks or use algorithms to predict the structure of proteins to enable faster drug discovery. RNA interference (RNAi) is an evolutionarily conserved gene silencing technique in which specific genes can be regulated and suppressed at the RNA level. T-cells are lymphocyte immune cells that protect the body from pathogens and cancer cells.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOne company is using a computer program to predict the 3D shape of proteins based on that protein\u0026rsquo;s amino acids. Predicting the structure makes it easier to design drug molecules that are more likely to bind to the protein.
